(6) 

โMUDโ has had a number of meanings, originally Multi-User Dungeon, or Multi-User Domain. A MOO is a โMUD, object-oriented.โ Sherry 
Turkleโs analysis of life in a MUD or MOO, [3mLife on the Screen: Identity in the Age of the Internet [0m(New York: Simon and Schuster, 
1995), is still a classic. See also Elizabeth Reid, โHierarchy and Power: Social Control in Cyberspace,โ in [3mCommunities in 
Cyberspace [0m, edited by Marc A. Smith and Peter Kollock (New York: Routledge, 1999), 107. The fatherโor godโof a MUD named 
LambdaMOO is Pavel Curtis. See his account in โMudding: Social Phenomena in Text-Based Virtual Realities,โ in Stefik, [3mInternet 
Dreams [0m, 265โ92. For two magical pages of links about the history of MUDs, see Lauren P. Burka, โThe MUDline,โ available at link 
#5; and Lauren P. Burka, โThe MUDdex,โ available at link #6. 

(7) 

This is not a rare feature of these spaces. It is indeed quite common, at least within role-playing games. Julian Dibbell 
described to me a โparableโ he recognized within Ultima Online: As he calls it, the โcase of the stolen Bone Crusher.โ โI got two 
offers for a Bone Crusher, which is a powerful sort of mace for bopping monsters over the head. I started dealing with both of 
them. At a certain point I was informed by one of them that the Bone Crusher had been stolen. So I said, โIโll go buy it from the 
other guy. But, by the way, who was it that stole the Bone Crusher, do you know?โ He said the name of the other guy. I was faced 
with this dilemma of was I going to serve as a fence for this other guy knowingly. And so, I turned to my mentor in this business, 
the guy who had been doing this for years and makes six figures a year on it, and, you know, I thought of him as an honest guy. So 
I sort of thought and maybe even hoped that he would just say just walk away. We donโt do these kinds of deals in our business. We 
donโt need that, you know, blah, blah, blah. But he said, โWell, you know, thieving is built into the game. It is a skill that you 
can do. So fair is fair.โ It is in the code that you can go into somebodyโs house and practice your thieving skills and steal 
something from them. And so, I went ahead and did the deal but there was this lingering sense of, โWow, in a way that is 
completely arbitrary that this ability is in the code here whereas, you know, if it wasnโt built into the code it would be another 
story; they would have stolen it in another wayโ โฆโ 

โBut in Ultima Online, it is very explicitly understood that the code allows you to steal and the rules allow you to steal. For me 
what was interesting was that there remains this gray area. It made it an interesting game, that you were allowed to do something 
that was actually morally shady and you might have to decide for yourself. Iโm not sure that now, going back to the deal, I would 
have taken the fenced item. Iโve been stolen from in the game, according to the rules, and it feels like shit.โ 

Audio Tape: Interview with Julian Dibbell (1/6/06) (on file with author).

(4) 

The design of the network has changed slightly in the years since this was written. Some authentication is now required on the 
Chicago network, but once Ethernet ports have been assigned an IP address, that address remains โas long as it doesnโt misbehave, 
we wonโt know that has happened. In that sense, it is much the way it was.โ Audio Tape: Interview with Greg Jackson (1/9/06) (on 
file with author). 

(5) 

See Helen Nissenbaum, โValues in the Design of Computer Systems,โ [3mComputers and Society [0m(March 1998): 38. 

(6) 

As network adminstrator Greg Jackson described to me, while certain ports (including the wireless network) require that the user 
initially register the machine, there is no ongoing effort to verify the identity of the user. And, more importantly, there are 
still a significant number of ports which remain essentially unregulated. That doesnโt mean that usage, however, isnโt regulated. 
As Jackson described, โBut the truth is, if we can identify a particular peer-to-peer network that is doing huge movie sharing, we 
will assign it a lower priority so it simply moves slower and doesnโt interfere with other people. So, we do a lot of packet 
shaping of that sort Almost never does that extend to actually blocking particular sites, for example, although there are a few 
cases where we have had to do that just because โฆโ 

According to Jackson, it is now Columbia that earns the reputation as the free-est network. โColumbia โฆ really doesnโt ever try to 
monitor at all who gets on the wired network on campus. They just donโt bother with that. Their policy is that they protect 
applications, not the network.โ Audio Tape: Interview with Greg Jackson (1/9/06) (on file with author).

see also Craig Hunt, [3mTCP/IP Network Administration, [0m2d ed. (Sebastopol, Cal.: OโReilly and Associates, 1998), 8โ22; [3mTrust in 
Cyberspace, [0medited by Fred B. Schneider (Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press, 1999), 29โ36. 

(8)

(9) 

In some contexts we call a network architecture that solves some of these โimperfectionsโโthat builds in these elements of 
controlโan intranet. Intranets are the fastest-growing portion of the Internet today. They are a strange hybrid of two traditions 
in network computingโthe open system of the Internet, based on TCP/IP, and the control-based capability of traditional proprietary 
networks layered onto the Internet. Intranets mix values from each to produce a network that is interoperable but gives its 
controller more control over access than anyone would have over the Internet. My argument in this book is that an โinternetโ with 
control is what our Internet is becoming.

(14) 

Whitfield Diffie and Martin E. Hellman, โNew Directions in Cryptography,โ [3mIEEE Transactions on Information Theory it-22 [0m(November 
1976): 29โ40. The idea had apparently been discovered earlier by James Ellis at the British Government Communication Headquarters, 
but it was not then published; see Baker and Hurst, [3mThe Limits of Trust, [0mxviiโxviii. 

(15) 

Even if the wires are tapped, this type of encryption still achieves its magic. We can get a hint of how in a series of cases 
whose accumulating impact makes the potential clear. (A) If I want to send a message to you that I know only you will be able to 
read, I can take your public key and use it to encrypt that message. Then I can send that message to you knowing that only the 
holder of the private key (presumably you) will be able to read it. Advantage: My message to you is secure. Disadvantage: You 
canโt be sure it is I who sent you the message. Because anyone can encrypt a message using your public key and then send it to 
you, you have no way to be certain that I was the one who sent it. Therefore, consider the next example. (B) Before I send the 
message I have encrypted with your public key, I can encrypt it with my private key. Then when you receive the message from me, 
you can first decrypt it with my public key, and then decrypt it again with your private key. After the first decryption, you can 
be sure that I (or the holder of my private key) was the one who sent you the message; after the second decryption, you can be 
sure that only you (or other holders of your private key) actually read the content of the message. But how do you know that what 
I say is the public key of Larry Lessig is actually the public key of Larry Lessig? How can you be sure, that is, that the public 
key you are using is actually the public key it purports to be? Here is where the next example comes in. (C) If there is a 
trustworthy third party (say, my bank, or the Federal Reserve Board, or the ACLU) with a public key (a fact I am able to verify 
because of the prominence of the institution), and that third party verifies that the public key of Larry Lessig is actually the 
public key of Larry Lessig, then along with my message sent to you, encrypted first in your public key and second in my private 
key, would be a certificate, issued by that institution, itself encrypted with the institutionโs private key. When you receive the 
message, you can use the institutionโs public key to decrypt the certificate; take from the certificate my public key (which you 
now are fairly confident is my public key); decrypt the message I sent you with the key held in the certificate (after which you 
are fairly confident comes from me); and then decrypt the message encrypted with your public key (which you can be fairly 
confident no one else has read). If we did all that, you would know that I am who I say I am and that the message was sent by me; 
I would know that only you read the message; and you would know that no one else read the message along the way.

Shawn C. Helms, โTranslating Privacy Values with Technology,โ [3mBoston University Journal of Science and Technology Law 7 [0m(2001):

Since [3mCode [0mv1, there has been an extensive debate about whether government intervention will be needed to effect important public 
values. See, e.g., Thomas B. Nachbar, โParadox and Structure: Relying on Government Regulation to Preserve the Internetโs 
Unregulated Character,โ [3mMinnesota Law Review [0m85 (2000): 215 (suggesting intervention needed); Neil Weinstock Netanel, โCyberspace 
Self-Governance: A Skeptical View from Liberal Democratic Theory,โ [3mCalifornia Law Review [0m88 (2000): 395 (surveying and emphasizing 
democratic deliberation); Jay P. Kesan, โPrivate Internet Governance,โ [3mLoyola University Chicago Law Journal [0m35 (2003): 87 
(surveying failed examples of private regulation); Thomas Schultz, โDoes Online Dispute Resolution Need Governmental Intervention? 
The Case for Architectures of Control and Trust,โ [3mNorth Carolina Journal of Law and Technology [0m6 (2004): 71; Carl Shapiro, โWill 
E-Commerce Erode Liberty?,โ [3mHarvard Business Review [0m(May-June 2000): 195. (optimistic about marketโs regulatory effect); Brett 
Frischmann, โPrivatization and Commercialization of the Internet Infrastructure: Rethinking Market Intervention into Government

Review 72 [0m(2004): 1497 (brilliant integration of game theory to understand when intervention is required).

(10) 

This is just what happened, Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals Chief Judge Richard Posner argues, when the Warren Court 
constitutionalized criminal procedure. To compensate for the increased difficulty in convicting a criminal, Congress radically 
increased criminal punishments. See Richard A. Posner, โThe Cost of Rights: Implications for Central and Eastern Europeโand for 
the United States,โ [3mTulsa Law Journal [0m32 (1996): 1, 7โ9. Professor William Stuntz has made a similar point. William J. Stuntz, 
โThe Uneasy Relationship Between Criminal Procedure and Criminal Justice,โ [3mYale Law Journal [0m107 (1997): 1, 4. The Constitution, in 
this story, acted as an exogenous constraint to which Congress could adjust. If the protections of the Constitution increased, 
then Congress could compensate by increasing punishments. 

(11) 

Initially, the CALEA requirements extended to โfacilities basedโ VOIP services only, though the push more recently is to extend it 
to all VOIP services. See Daniel J. Solove, Marc Rotenberg, and Paul M. Schwartz, [3mInformation Privacy Law, [0m2nd edition (New York: 
Aspen Publishers, 2006), they summarize the VOIP situation on pp. 287-88: โVoice over Internet Protocol (VoIP).โ 

(12) 

See Federal Communications Commission, Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking, Released November, 5 1998, at p. 25 (โIn the matter 
of: Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Actโ) (โJ-STD-025 includes a โlocationโ parameter that would identify the 
location of a subjectโs โmobile terminalโ whenever this information is reasonably available at the intercept access point and its 
delivery to law enforcement is legally authorized. Location information would be available to the LEA irrespective of whether a 
call content channel or a call data channel was employedโ). The FBIโs desire to gather this information was challenged by civil 
liberties groups and industry associations. See [3mUnited States Telecom Association, et al. v. FCC, [0m227 F.3d 450 (D.C. Cir. 2000). 
The Court permitted the cell tower information to be revealed, but only with a more substantial burden placed on the government.

over Lotus Marketplace and the Clipper Chip [0m(New Haven: Yale University Press, 1997), 32โ43. For a sample of various views, see 
Kirsten Scheurer, โThe Clipper Chip: Cryptography Technology and the Constitution,โ [3mRutgers Computer and Technology Law Journal [0m21 
(1995): 263; cf. Howard S. Dakoff, โThe Clipper Chip Proposal: Deciphering the Unfounded Fears That Are Wrongfully Derailing Its 
Implementation,โ [3mJohn Marshall Law Review [0m29 (1996): 475. โClipper was adopted as a federal information-processing standard for 
voice communicationโ in 1994; see [3mGurak, Persuasion and Privacy in Cyberspace, [0m125. 

(18) 

See Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), [3mCracking DES: Secrets of Encryption Research, Wiretap Politics, and Chip Design [0m
(Sebastopol, Cal.: Electronic Frontier Foundation, 1998), ch. 1. 

(19) 

For a good summary of the Clipper scheme, see Baker and Hurst, [3mThe Limits of Trust, [0m15โ18; A. Michael Froomkin, โThe Metaphor Is 
the Key: Cryptography, the Clipper Chip, and the Constitution,โ [3mUniversity of Pennsylvania Law Review [0m143 (1995): 709, 752โ59. For 
a more technical discussion, see Bruce Schneier, [3mApplied Cryptography: Protocols, Algorithms, and Source Code in C, [0m2d ed. (New 
York: Wiley, 1996): 591โ93. 

(20) 

See Richard Field, โ1996: Survey of the Yearโs Developments in Electronic Cash Law and the Laws Affecting Electronic Banking in 
the United States,โ 46 [3mAmerican University Law Review ( [0m1997): 967, 993, n.192. 

(21) 

See A. Michael Froomkin, โIt Came from Planet Clipper: The Battle over Cryptographic Key โEscrow,โโ [3mUniversity of Chicago Legal 
Forum 1996 [0m(1996): 15, 32.

Anick Jesdanun, โAttacks Renew Debate Over Encryption Software,โ [3mChicago Tribune, [0mSeptember 28, 2001, available at link #31. 

(23) 

lay P. Kesan and Rajiv C. Shah, Shaping Code, 18 [3mHarvard Journal of Law and Technology [0m319, 326-27 (2005). 

(24) 

Former Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, for example, has called a national ID card โan infringement on rights of Americansโ; 
see Ann Devroy, โThornburgh Rules Out Two Gun Control Options; Attorney General Objects to Registration Card for Gun Owners, 
National Identification Card,โ [3mWashington Post, [0mJune 29, 1989, A41. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 (Public Law 
99โ603, 100 Stat 3359 [1986], 8 USC 1324a[c] [1988]) eschews it: โNothing in this section shall be construed to authorize directly 
or indirectly, the issuance or use of national identification cards or the establishment of national identification cards.โ Given 
the power of the network to link data, however, this seems to me an empty protection. See also Real ID Act, Pub. L. No. 109โ13, 
Title II ยง202 (2005). The Real ID Act requires citizens to go to the DMV in person, bringing with them several pieces of 
identification to the DMV, including birth certificates, and face consumers with higher fees and tougher background check. 
Supporters feel the act targets the link between terrorists, illegal immigrants, and identification standards. 

(25) 

Jack Goldsmith and Timothy Wu, โDigital Borders,โ [3mLegal Affairs, [0mJan./Feb. 2006, 44. 

(26) 

Notice that this would be an effective end-run around the protections that the Court recognized in [3mReno v. American Civil 
Liberties Union, [0m117 SCt 2329 (1997). There are many โactivitiesโ on the Net that Congress could easily regulate (such as 
gambling). Regulation of these activities could require IDs before access to these activities would be permitted. To the extent 
that such regulation increases the incidence of IDs on the Net, other speech-related access conditions would become easier to 
justify. 

(27) 

Arthur Cordell and T. Ran Ide have proposed the consideration of a bit tax; see Arthur J. Cordell et al., [3mThe New Wealth of 
Nations: Taxing Cyberspace [0m(Toronto: Between the Lines, 1997). Their arguments are compelling from the perspective of social 
justice and economics, but what they do not account for is the architecture that such a taxing system would require. A Net 
architected to meter a bit tax could be architected to meter just about anything. 

(28) 

Countries with such a requirement have included Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Greece, Italy, and Switzerland; see Richard L. 
Hasen, โSymposium: Law, Economics, and Norms: Voting Without Law?โ [3mUniversity of Pennsylvania Law Review [0m144 (1996): 2135. 

(29) 

See the description in Scott Bradner, โThe Internet Engineering Task Force,โ in [3mOpen Sources: Voices from the Open Source 
Revolution, [0medited by Chris DiBona et al. (Sebastopol, Cal.: OโReilly and Associates, 1999). 

(30) 

Michael Froomkin makes a similar point: โExport control rules have had an effect on the domestic market for products with 
cryptographic capabilities such as e-mail, operating systems, and word processors. Largely because of the ban on export of strong 
cryptography, there is today no strong mass-market standard cryptographic product within the U.S. even though a considerable 
mathematical and programming base is fully capable of creating oneโ; โIt Came from Planet Clipper,โ 19.

Cisco has developed products that incorporate the use of network-layer encryption through the IP Security (IPSec) protocol. For a 
brief discussion of IPSec, see Cisco Systems, Inc., โIP Security-IPSec Overview,โ available at link #33. For a more extensive 
discussion, see Cisco Systems, Inc., โCisco IOS Software Feature: Network-Layer EncryptionโWhite Paperโ; Cisco Systems, Inc. 
โIPSecโWhite Paper,โ available at link #34; see also Dawn Bushaus, โEncryption Can Help ISPs Deliver Safe Services,โ [3mTele.Com, [0m

(34) 

Little, but not nothing. Through conditional spending grants, the government was quite effective initially in increasing Net 
participation, and it was effective in resisting the development of encryption technologies; see Whitfield Diffie and Susan Eva 
Landau, [3mPrivacy on the Line: The Politics of Wiretapping and Encryption [0m(Cambridge, Mass.: MIT Press, 1998). Steven Levy tells of 
a more direct intervention. When Richard Stallman refused to password-protect the MIT AI (artificial intelligence) machine, the 
Department of Defense threatened to take the machine off the Net unless the architectures were changed to restrict access. For 
Stallman, this was a matter of high principle; for the Department of Defense, it was business as usual; see Steven Levy, [3mHackers: 
Heroes of the Computer Revolution [0m(Garden City, N.Y.: Anchor Press/Doubleday, 1984), 416โ18.

techniques for security, see [3mTrust in Cyberspace, [0medited by Fred B. Schneider (Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press, 1999), 
123-24, 133-34.

(1) 

Mike Godwin, [3mCyber Rights: Defending Free Speech in the Digital Age [0m(New York: Times Books, 1998), 15. See also Esther Dyson, [3m
Release 2.0: A Design for Living in the Digital Age [0m(New York: Broadway Books, 1997), who asserts: โUsed right, the Internet can 
be a powerful enabling technology fostering the development of communities because it supports the very thing that creates a 
communityโhuman interactionโ (32); see also Stephen Doheny-Farina, [3mThe Wired Neighborhood [0m(New Haven, Conn.: Yale University 
Press, 1996), 121โ37. For an important collection examining community in cyberspace, see Marc A. Smith and Peter Kollock, [3m
Communities in Cyberspace [0m(New York: Routledge, 1999). The collection ranges across the social issues of community, including 
โsocial order and control,โ โcollective action,โ โcommunity structure and dynamics,โ and โidentity.โ The same relationship between 
architecture and norms assumed in this chapter guides much of the analysis in Smith and Kollockโs collection. 

(2) 

As I explored in [3mCode [0mv1, the newest โcommunitarianโ on the Net might be business. A number of influential works have argued that 
the key to success with online businesses is the development of โvirtual communitiesโ; see, for example, Larry Downes and Chunka 
Mui, [3mUnleashing the Killer App: Digital Strategies for Market Dominance [0m(Boston: Harvard Business School Press, 1998), 101โ9; John 
Hagel and Arthur G. Armstrong, Net Gain: Expanding Markets Through Virtual Communities (Boston: Harvard Business School Press, 
1997). The explosion of essentially community based entities, such as Wikipedia and MySpace, in the time since confirms the 
insight of these authors. 

(3) 

For a detailed study of Internet demographics, see E-Consultancy, [3mInternet Statistics Compendium, [0mApril 12, 2006, available at 
link #36. 

(4) 

For a great sense of how it was, see the articles by Rheingold, Barlow, Bruckman, and Ramo in part 4 of Richard Holeton, [3mComposing 
Cyberspace: Identity, Community, and Knowledge in the Electronic Age [0m(Boston: McGraw-Hill, 1998). Howard Rheingoldโs book (the 
first chapter of which is excerpted in Holetons book) is also an early classic; see [3mThe Virtual Community: Homesteading on the 
Electronic Frontier [0m(Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley, 1993). Stacy Hornโs book is a brilliant text taken more directly from the 
interchange (and more) online; see [3mCyberville: Clicks, Culture, and the Creation of an Online Town [0m(New York: Warner Books, 1998). 

(5)

(1997): 495. 

(6) 

As Steven Johnson puts it: โIn theory, these are examples of architecture and urban planning, but in practice they are bound up in 
broader issues: each design decision echoes and amplifies a set of values, an assumption about the larger society that frames itโ; [3m
Interface Culture: How New Technology Transforms the Way We Create and Communicate [0m(San Francisco: Harper, 1997), 44. See also 
Nelson Goodman, โHow Buildings Mean,โ in [3mReconceptions in Phi [0m[3mlosophy and Other Arts and Sciences, [0medited by Nelson Goodman and 
Catherine Z. Elgin (London: Routledge, 1988), 31โ48. The same insight applies to things as well as spaces. See Langdon Winner, โDo 
Artifacts Have Politics?,โ in [3mThe Whale and the Reactor: A Search for Limits in an Age of High Technology [0m(Chicago: University of 
Chicago Press, 1986), 19โ39. To say a space or thing has values, however, does not say it determines any particular result. 
Influences and agency are many.

See Laura J. Gurak, [3mPersuasion and Privacy in Cyberspace: The Online Protests over Lotus, Marketplace, and the Clipper Chip [0m(New

exchanges of tense text maniacs. Like meโ; [3mCyber Rights, [0m45. 

(11) 

This is what economists would call a โseparating equilibriumโ: โplayers of different types adopt different strategies and thereby 
allow an uninformed player to draw inferences about an informed playerโs type from that playerโs actionsโ; Douglas G. Baird, 
Robert H. Gertner, and Randal C. Picker, [3mGame Theory and the Law [0m(Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1994), 314. William 
Mitchell argues that the advance back to synchronous communication is not necessarily an advantage: โAs much more efficient 
asynchronous communications systems have become commonplace, though, we have seen that strict synchrony is not always desirable; 
controlled asynchrony may have its advantagesโ; [3mCity of Bits, [0m5โ16.

(17) 

As stated in AOLโs Terms of Service (TOS): โAs an AOL member you are required to follow our TOS no matter where you are on the 
Internet.โ Some of the other terms of service include the following rules: โLanguage: Mild expletives and nonsexual anatomical 
references are allowed, but strong vulgar language, crude or explicit sexual references, hate speech, etc., are not. If you see 
it, report it at Keyword: Notify AOL. Nudity: Photos containing revealing attire or limited nudity in a scientific or artistic 
context are okay in some places (not all). Partial or full frontal nudity is not okay. If you see it, report it at Keyword: Notify 
AOL. Sex/Sensuality: There is a difference between affection and vulgarity. There is also a difference between a discussion of the 
health or emotional aspects of sex using appropriate language, and more crude conversations about sex. The former is acceptable, 
the latter is not. For example, in a discussion about forms of cancer, the words breast or testicular would be acceptable, but 
slang versions of those words would not be acceptable anywhere. Violence and Drug Abuse: Graphic images of humans being killed, 
such as in news accounts, may be acceptable in some areas, but blood and gore, gratuitous violence, etc., are not acceptable. 
Discussions about coping with drug abuse in health areas are okay, but discussions about or depictions of illegal drug abuse that 
imply it is acceptable are not.โ

Politics. The end was approaching and this was viewed as a virtual lifeboat for the devoted and cohesive community that had 
thrived on CC. About 100 CC survivors washed up together to settle in these new forums. Both were established as being private but 
members were allowed to invite friends.โ

(67) 

The most significant cost is on innovation. If the broadcast flag requirement reaches any device capable of demodulating digital 
television, then its requirement reaches any digital device on the network. It would be the first time network applications would 
have to comply with a technical mandate of such breadth, and it would be an unmanageable burden for open source and free software 
deployments. 

(68) 

R. Polk Wagner, [3mOn Software Regulation, Southern California Law Review [0m78 (2005): 457, 470-71. See also Joel R. Reidenberg, 
โTechnology and Internet Jurisdiction,โ [3mUniversity of Pennsylvania Law Review [0m153 (2005): 1951; Joshua A. T. Fairfield, โCracks in 
the Foundation: The New Internet Legislationโs Hidden Threat to Privacy and Commerce,โ [3mArizona State Law Journal [0m36 (2004): 1193 
(arguing Congress should be more jurisdictionally exceptional and less content exceptional in its regulation of cyberspace).

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุณุงุจุน: ูุง ุชูุธูููู ุงูุฃุดูุงุก [0m

(1) 

Or more precisely, against a certain form of government regulation. The more powerful libertarian arguments against regulation in 
cyberspace are advanced, for example, by Peter Huber in [3mLaw and Disorder in Cyberspace. [0mHuber argues against agency regulation and 
in flavor of regulation by the common law. See also Thomas Hazlett in โThe Rationality of U.S. Regulation of the Broadcast 
Spectrum,โ [3mJournal of Law and Economics [0m33 (1990): 133, 133โ39. For a lawyer, it is hard to understand precisely what is meant by 
โthe common law.โ The rules of the common law are many, and the substantive content has changed. There is a common law process, 
which lawyers like to mythologize, in which judges make policy decisions in small spaces against the background of binding 
precedent. It might be this that Huber has in mind, and if so, there are, of course, benefits to this system. But as he plainly 
understands, it is a form of regulation [3meven [0mif it is constituted differently. 

(2) 

The primary examples are the convictions under the Espionage Act of 1917; see, for example, [3mSchenck v. United States, [0m249 US 47 
(1919) (upholding conviction for distributing a leaflet attacking World War I conscription); [3mFrohwerk v. United States, [0m249 US 204 
(1919) (upholding conviction based on newspaper alleged to cause disloyalty); [3mDebs v. United States, [0m249 US 211 (1919) (conviction 
upheld for political speech said to cause insubordination and disloyalty). 

(3) 

See, for example, the work of John R. Commons, [3mLegal Foundations of Capitalism [0m(1924), 296โ98, discussed in Herbert Hovenkamp, [3m
Enterprise and American Law, 1836โ1937 [0m(Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1991), 235; see also John R. Commons, [3m
Institutional Economics: Its Place in Political Economy [0m(1934) (New Brunswick, N.J.: Transaction Publishers reprint, 1990). 

(4) 

The general idea is that the tiny corrections of space enforce a discipline, and that this discipline is an important regulation. 
Such theorizing is a tiny part of the work of Michel Foucault; see [3mDiscipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison [0m(New York: 
Vintage, 1979), 170โ77, though his work generally inspires this perspective. It is what Oscar Gandy speaks about in [3mThe Panoptic 
Sort: A Political Economy of Personal Information [0m(Boulder: Westview Press, 1993), 23. David Brin makes the more general point 
that I am arguingโthat the threat to liberty is broader than a threat by the state; see [3mThe Transparent Society, [0m110. 

(5) 

See, for example, [3mThe Built Environment: A Creative Inquiry into Design and Planning, [0medited by Tom J. Bartuska and Gerald L. 
Young (Menlo Park, Cal.: Crisp Publications, 1994); [3mPreserving the Built Heritage: Tools for Implementation, [0medited by J. Mark 
Schuster et al. (Hanover, N.H.: University Press of New England, 1997). In design theory, the notion I am describing accords with 
the tradition of Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk; see, for example, William Lennertz, โTown-Making Fundamentals,โ in [3m
Towns and Town-Making Principles, [0medited by Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk (New York: Rizzoli, 1991): โThe work of โฆ 
Duany and โฆ Plater-Zyberk begins with the recognition that design affects behavior. [They] see the structure and function of a 
community as interdependent. Because of this, they believe a designerโs decisions will permeate the lives of residents not just 
visually but in the way residents live. They believe design structures functional relationships, quantitatively and qualitatively, 
and that it is a sophisticated tool whose power exceeds its cosmetic attributesโ (21). 

(6)

Do,โ in Schuster, [3mPreserving the Built Heritage, [0m3), but it describes four tools whereas Schuster describes five. I develop the 
understanding of the approach in the Appendix to this book.

(23) 

Interestinglyโand again, a reason to see the future of regulation talk located elsewhereโthis is not true of architects. An 
example is the work of John de Monchaux and J. Mark Schuster. In their essay โFive Things to Doโ and in the collection that essay 
introduces, [3mPreserving the Built Heritage, [0mthey describe the โfive and only five things that governments can doโfive distinct 
tools that they can useโto implement theirโ policies (4-5): ownership and operation (the state may own the resource); regulation 
(of either individuals or institutions); incentives; property rights; information. Monchaux and Schusterโs five tools map in a 
complex way on the structure I have described, but significantly, we share a view of regulation as a constant trade-off between 
tools.

(36)

(37) 

Consider civil rights in the American South. During the legislative hearings on the Civil Rights Act of 1964, supporters of the 
bill called before the committee white, southern employers and business owners whose discrimination against blacks was the prime 
target of the legislation. Some of these employers and businessmen supported the bill because business would improve: The labor 
pool would increase, causing wages to decrease, and the demand for services would increaseโso long, that is, as whites did not 
shift their custom. This last point is what set the stage for business support for the Civil Rights Act. What business leaders 
feared was the retaliation of whites against their voluntary efforts to integrate. The Civil Rights Act changed the context to 
make discrimination against blacks illegal. The businessman could thenโwithout fear of the retaliation of whitesโhire or serve a 
black because of either his concern for the status of blacks or his concern to obey the law. By creating this ambiguity, the law 
reduced the symbolic costs of hiring blacks. This example demonstrates how law can change norms without government having control 
over the norms. In this case, the norm of accommodating blacks was changed by giving it a second meaningโthe norm of simply 
obeying the law; see Lessig, โThe Regulation of Social Meaning,โ 965โ67. 

(38) 

Thurgood Marshall, Esq., oral argument on behalf of respondents, [3mCooper [0mv. [3mAaron, [0m358 US 1 (1958) (no. 1), in [3mFifty-four Landmark 
Briefs and Arguments of the Supreme Court of the United States: Constitutional Law, [0medited by Philip B. Kurland and Gerhard Casper 
(Washington, D.C.: University Publications of America, 1975), 533, 713. 

(39) 

See, for example, Dyson, [3mRelease 2.0: [0mโGovernment can play a divisive role vis-ร-vis communities. Often, the more government 
provides, the less community members themselves contributeโ (43); in โThe Regulation of Groups: The Influence of Legal and 
Nonlegal Sanctions on Collective Actionโ ( [3mUniversity of Chicago Law Review [0m63 [1996]: 133), Eric A. Posner argues that government 
help to a community can undermine the community.

(43) 

Cass Sunstein points to seatbelt law as a hypothetical of โgovernment regulation permit[ing] people to express preferences by 
using the shield of the law to lessen the risk that private actors will interfere with the expression [through normative 
censure]โ; โLegal Interference with Private Preferences,โ [3mUniversity of Chicago Law Review [0m53 (1986): 1129, 1145. Alternatively, 
seatbelt laws have been used as the factual basis for critiques of norm sponsorship as ineffective and no substitute for direct 
regulation; see Robert S. Alder and R. David Pittle, โCajolery or Command: Are Education Campaigns an Adequate Substitute for 
Regulation?โ [3mYale Journal on Regulation [0m1 (1984): 159, 171โ78. However, the observations may have been premature. John C. Wright, 
commenting on televisionโs normative content, claims that โwe have won the battle on seatbelts, just by a bunch of people getting 
together and saying, โIt is indeed macho to put on a seatbelt. It is macho and it is smart and it is manly and it is also feminine 
and smart and savvy and charming to put on a seatbeltโโ; Charles W. Gusewelle et al., โRound Table Discussion: Violence in the 
Media,โ [3mKansas Journal of Law and Public Policy [0m4 (1995): 39, 47.

(47)

Federal Criminal Law,โ [3mBuffalo Criminal Law Review [0m1 (1997): 137. 

(48) 

In the mid-1970s the U.S. government sponsored a campaign to spray paraquat (a herbicide that causes lung damage to humans) on the 
Mexican marijuana crop. This sparked a public outcry that resulted in congressional suspension of funding in 1978. However, 
following a congressional amendment in 1981, paraquat spraying was used on the domestic marijuana crop during the 1980s. The 
publicity surrounding the use of paraquat in Mexico is generally believed to have created a boom in the domestic marijuana 
industry and also an increase in the popularity of cocaine during the 1980s. See generally Michael Isikoff, โDEA Finds Herbicides 
in Marijuana Samples,โ [3mWashington Post, [0mJuly 26, 1989, 17. In โDrug Diplomacy and the Supply-Side Strategy: A Survey of United 
States Practiceโ ( [3mVanderbilt Law Review [0m43 [1990]: 1259, 1275 n.99), Sandi R. Murphy gives a full history of the laws passed 
relevant to paraquat; see also โA Cure Worse Than the Disease?,โ [3mTime, [0mAugust 29, 1983, 20.

[3mRoe v. Wade, [0m410 US 113 (1973).

[3mRust v. Sullivan, [0m500 US 173 (1991). 

(51) 

[3mMaher v. Roe, [0m432 US 464 (1977). 

(52) 

[3mHodgson v. Minnesota, [0m497 US 417 (1990). 

(53) 

This distinction between โdirectโ and โindirectโ regulation, of course, has a long and troubled history in philosophy as well as 
in law. Judith J. Thomson describes this difference in her distinction between the trolley driver who must run over one person to 
save five and the surgeon who may not harvest the organs from one healthy person to save five dying people; see โThe Trolley 
Problem,โ [3mYale Law Journal [0m94 (1985): 1395, 1395-96. This difference is also known as the โdouble effect doctrine,โ discussed in 
Philippa Foot, โThe Problem of Abortion and the Doctrine of the Double Effect,โ in [3mVirtues and Vices and Other Essays in Moral 
Philosophy [0m(Berkeley: University of California Press, 1978), 19. See also Thomas J. Bole III, โThe Doctrine of Double Effect: Its 
Philosophical Viability,โ [3mSouthwest Philosophy Review [0m7 (1991): 91; Frances M. Kamm, โThe Doctrine of Double Effect: Reflections 
on Theoretical and Practical [3mIssues,โ Journal of Medicine and Philosophy [0m16 (1991): 571; Warren Quinn, โActions, Intentions, and 
Consequences: The Doctrine of Double Effect,โ [3mPhilosophy and Public Affairs [0m18 (1989): 334. The trouble in these cases comes when 
a line between them must be drawn; here I do not need to draw any such line. 

(54) 

Richard Craswell suggests other examples making the same point: The government could (a) regulate product quality or safety 
directly or (b) disclose information about different productsโ quality or safety ratings, in the hope that manufacturers would 
then have an incentive to compete to improve those ratings; the government could (a) allow an industry to remain monopolized and 
attempt directly to regulate the price the monopolist charged or (b) break up the monopolist into several competing firms, in the 
hope that competition would then force each to a more competitive price; the government could (a) pass regulations directly 
requiring corporations to do various things that would benefit the public interest or (b) pass regulations requiring that 
corporate boards of directors include a certain number of โindependentโ representatives, in the hope that the boards would then 
decide for themselves to act more consistently with the public interest.

See New York v. United States, 505 US 144 (1992).

(63) 

Michael Froomkin points to the Clipper chip regulations as another example. By using the standards-setting process for government 
purchases, the federal government could try to achieve a standard for encryption without adhering to the Administrative Procedure 
Act. โA stroke of bureaucratic genius lay at the heart of the Clipper strategy. Congress had not, and to this date has not, given 
the executive branch the power to control the private use of encryption. Congress has not even given the executive the power to 
set up an escrow system for keys. In the absence of any formal authority to prevent the adoption of unescrowed cryptography, 
Clipperโs proponents hit upon the idea of using the governmentโs power as a major consumer of cryptographic products to rig the 
market. If the government could not prevent the public from using nonconforming products, perhaps it could set the standard by 
purchasing and deploying large numbers of escrowed productsโ; โIt Came from Planet Clipper,โ 15, 24, 1โ33.

(9) 

Craig Hunt, [3mTCP/IP: Network Administration [0m(Sebastopol, Calif.: OโReilly and Associates, 1997), 1โ22, 6, 8; Loshin, [3mTCP/IP:

(10) 

There is no standard reference model for the TCP/IP layers. Hunt refers to the four layers as the โnetwork access,โ โinternet,โ 
โhost-to-host transport,โ and โapplicationโ layers; [3mTCP/IP: Network Administration, [0m9. Loshin uses the terminology I follow in the 
text; [3mTCP/IP: Clearly Explained, [0m13โ17. Despite the different moniker, the functions performed in each of these layers are 
consistent. As with any protocol stack model, data are โpassed down the stack when it is being sent to the network, and up the 
stack when it is being received from the network.โ Each layer โhas its own independent data structures,โ with one layer โunaware 
of the data structures used byโ other layers; Hunt, [3mTCP/IP: Network Administration, [0m9. 

(11) 

Hunt, TCP/IP: Network Administration, 9; Loshin, TCP/IP: Clearly Explained, 13โ17. 

(12) 

As Hafner and Lyon explain: โThe general view was that any protocol was a potential building block, and so the best approach was 
to define simple protocols, each limited in scope, with the expectation that any of them might someday be joined or modified in 
various unanticipated ways. The protocol design philosophy adopted by the NWG [network working group] broke ground for what came 
to be widely accepted as the โlayeredโ approach to protocolsโ; [3mWhere Wizards Stay Up Late, [0m147. 

(13) 

The fights over encryption at the link level, for example, are fights over the TCP/IP protocols. Some within the network industry 
have proposed that encryption be done at the gateways, with a method for dumping plain text at the gateways if there were proper 
legal authorityโa kind of โprivate doorbellโ for resolving the encryption controversy; see Elizabeth Kaufman and Roszel Thomsen 
II, โThe Export of Certain Networking Encryption Products Under ELAs,โ available at link #57. This has been opposed by the 
Internet Architectural Board (LAB) as inconsistent with the โend-to-endโ architecture of the Internet; see IAB statement on 
โprivate doorbellโ encryption, available at link #58. Since [3mCode [0mv1, there has been an explosion of excellent work extending 
โlayer theory.โ Perhaps the best academic work in this has been Lawrence B. Solum and Minn Chung, โThe Layers Principle: Internet 
Architecture and the Law,โ University of San Diego Public Law Research Paper No. 55, available at link #59. Solum and Chung have 
used the idea of Internet layers to guide regulatory policy, locating appropriate and inappropriate targets for regulatory 
intervention. This is an example of some of the best work integrating technology and legal policy, drawing interesting and 
important implications from the particular, often counter intuitive, interaction between the two. I introduce โlayersโ in my own 
work in [3mThe Future of Ideas: The Fate of the Commons in a Connected World [0m(New York: Random House, 2001), 23โ25. See also Yochai 
Benkler, [3mThe Wealth of Networks: How Social Production Transforms Markets and Freedom [0m(New Haven: Yale University Press, 2006), 
391โ97. For other very useful work extending this analysis, see Craig McTaggart, โA Layered Approach to Internet Legal Analysis,โ [3m
McGill Law Journal [0m48 (2003): 571; Thomas A. Lane, โOf Hammers and Saws: The i Toolbox of Federalism and Sources of Law for the 
Web,โ [3mNew Mexico Law Review [0m33 (2003): 115; Jane Bailey, โOf Mediums and Metaphors: How a Layered Methodology Might Contribute to 
Constitutional Analysis of Internet Content Regulation,โ [3mManitoba Law Journal [0m30 (2004): 197. 

(14) 

See Hafher and Lyon, [3mWhere Wizards Stay up Late, [0m174. 

(15) 

A 1994 HTML manual lists twenty-nine different browsers; see Larry Aronson, [3mHTML Manual of Style [0m(Emeryville, Cal.: Ziff-Davis 
Press, 1994), 124โ26. 

(16) 

Source code is the code that programmers write. It sometimes reads like a natural language, but it is obviously not. A program is 
(ordinarily) written in source code, but to be run it must be converted into a language the computer can process. This is what a 
โcompilerโ does. Some source code is converted on the flyโBASIC, for example, is usually interpreted, meaning the computer 
compiles the source code as it is run. โObject codeโ is machine-readable. It is an undifferentiated string of 0s and 1s that 
instructs the machines about the tasks it is to perform. 

(17) 

Hypertext is text that is linked to another location in the same document or in another document located either on the Net or on 
the same computer. 

(18) 

T. Berners-Lee and R. Cailliau, [3mWorldWideWeb: Proposal for a HyperText Project, [0m1990, available at link #60. 

(19) 

Of course, not always. When commercial production of computers began, software was often a free addition to the computer. Its 
commercial development as proprietary came only later; see Ira V. Heffan, โCopyleft: Licensing Collaborative Works in the Digital 
Age,โ [3mStanford Law Review [0m49 (1997): 1487, 1492-93. 

(20) 

At the time Linux was developed, the dominant thinking among computer scientists was against a monolithic operating system 
operating out of a single kernel and in favor of a โmicrokernelโโbased system. MINIX, a microkernel system, was the primary 
competitor at the time. Torvalds consciously rejected this โmodernโ thinking and adopted the โtraditionalโ model for Linux; see 
โThe Tanenbaum-Torvalds Debate,โ in [3mOpen Sources: Voices from the Open Source Revolution, [0medited by Chris DiBona et al. 
(Sebastopol, Cal.: OโReilly and Associates, 1999), 221โ51. 

(21) 

See the lists, โPorts of Linuxโ and Linux Online, โHardware Port Projectsโ available at link #61 and link #62. 

(22) 

Technically, it does not sit in the public domain. Code from these open source projects is copyrighted and licensed. GNU/Linux is 
licensed under the GNU GPL, which limits the possible use you can make of Linux; essentially, you cannot take the public part and 
close it, and you cannot integrate the open part with the closed; see Bruce Perens, โThe Open Source Definition,โ in DiBona et 
al., [3mOpen Sources, [0m181-82. But for purposes of future open source development, the code sits in the commons. On the idea and 
values of the commons, see, for example, Michael A. Heller, โThe Tragedy of the Anticommons: Property in the Transition from Marx 
to Markets,โ [3mHarvard Law Review [0m111 (1998): 621; Stephen M. Mcjohn, โFair Use and Privatization in Copyright,โ [3mSan Diego Law 
Review [0m35 (1998): 61; Mark A. Lemley, โThe Economics of Improvement in Intellectual Property Law,โ [3mTexas Law Review [0m75 (1997): 
989; Mark A. Lemley, โRomantic Authorship and the Rhetoric of Property,โ [3mTexas Law Review [0m75 (1997): 873; Jessica Litman, โThe 
Public Domain,โ [3mEmory Law Journal [0m39 (1990): 965; Carol M. Rose, โThe Several Futures of Property: Of Cyberspace and Folk Tales, 
Emission Trades and Ecosystems,โ [3mMinnesota Law Review 83 [0m(1998): 129. 

(23) 

Daniel Benoliel, โTechnological Standards, Inc.: Rethinking Cyberspace Regulatory Epistemology,โ [3mCalifornia Law Review [0m92 (2004): 
1069, 1114. 

(24) 

Peter Harter, โThe Legal and Policy Framework for Global Electronic Commerce,โ comments at the Berkeley Center for Law and 
Technology Conference, March 5-6, 1999. 

(25)

(26)

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุชุงุณุน: ุงูุชุฑุฌูุฉ [0m

Principles,โ [3mHarvard Law Review [0m107 (1994): 820, 830โ34; William J. Stuntz, โThe Substantive Origins of Criminal Procedure,โ [3mYale

(15) 

โTranslationโ is not Brandeisโs term, though it is a term of the courts. The idea is best captured by Justice Robert H. Jackson in [3m
West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette, [0m319 US 624, 639-40 (1943): โNor does our duty to apply the Bill of Rights to 
assertions of official authority depend upon our possession of marked competence in the field where the invasion of rights occurs. 
True, the task of translating the majestic generalities of the Bill of Rights, conceived as part of the pattern of liberal 
government in the eighteenth century, into concrete restraints on officials dealing with the problems of the twentieth century, is 
one to disturb self-confidence. These principles grew in soil which also produced a philosophy that the individual was the center 
of society, that his liberty was attainable through mere absence of governmental restraints, and that government should be 
entrusted with few controls and only the mildest supervision over menโs affairs. We must transplant these rights to a soil in 
which the laissez-faire concept or principle of non-interference has withered at least as to economic affairs, and social 
advancements are increasingly sought through closer integration of society and through expanded and strengthened governmental 
controls. These changed conditions often deprive precedents of reliability and cast us more than we would choose upon our own 
judgment. But we act in these matters not by authority of our competence but by force of our commissions. We cannot, because of 
modest estimates of our competence in such specialties as public education, withhold the judgment that history authenticates as 
the function of this Court when liberty is infringed.โ 

(16) 

See Robert Post, [3mConstitutional Domains: Democracy, Community, Management [0m(Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1995), 
60โ64. 

(17) 

See Lessig, โFidelity in Translation,โ 1214โ68; Lawrence Lessig, โTranslating Federalism: United States v Lopez,โ [3mSupreme Court 
Review [0m1995 (1995): 125, 146. For a more sophisticated analysis of how changing technologies in the context of telecommunications 
is affecting legislation and judicial doctrine, see Monroe E. Price and John F. Duffy, โTechnological Change and Doctrinal 
Persistence: Telecommunications Reform in Congress and the Court,โ [3mColumbia Law Review [0m97 (1997): 976. 

(18) 

So, for example, the translations to support federalism are translations on the right, while the translations to support criminal 
rights are translations on the left. 

(19) 

[3mKatz v. United States, [0m389 US 347, 353 (1967). 

(20) 

Laurence H. Tribe, โThe Constitution in Cyberspace: Law and Liberty Beyond the Electronic Frontier,โ address at the First 
Conference on Computers, Freedom, and Privacy, March 26, 1991, reprinted in [3mThe Humanist [0m(September-October 1991): 15, 20-21. 

(21) 

[3mKatz v. United States [0m, 389 US 347, 351 (1967). 

(22) 

As the history of the Fourth Amendmentโs protection of privacy since Katz will attest, the technique used by Stewart was in the 
end quite ineffectual. When tied to property notions, no doubt the reach of the Fourth Amendment was narrow. But at least its 
reach went as far as the reach of property. Because โpropertyโ is a body of law independent of privacy questions, it was resilient 
to the pressures that privacy placed on it But once the Court adopted the โreasonable expectation of privacyโ test, it could later 
restrict these โreasonable expectationsโ in the Fourth Amendment context, with little consequence outside that context The result 
has been an ever-decreasing scope for privacyโs protection. 

(23) 

See Lessig, โTranslating Federalism,โ 206โ11. 

(24) 

Tribe, โThe Constitution in Cyberspace,โ 15. 

(25) 

See Lawrence Lessig, โReading the Constitution in Cyberspace,โ [3mEmory Law Journal [0m45 (1996): 869, 872.

See Tribe, โThe Constitution in Cyberspace,โ 15. 

(28) 

โA latent ambiguity arises from extraneous or collateral facts which make the meaning of a written instrument uncertain although 
the language thereof be clear and unambiguous. The usual instance of a latent ambiguity is one in which a writing refers to a 
particular person or thing and is thus apparently clear on its face, but upon application to external objects is found to fit two 
or more of them equallyโ; [3mWilliston on Contracts, [0m3d ed., edited by Walter H. E. Jaeger (Mount Kisco, N.Y.: Baker, Voorhis, 1957), 
627, 898.

[1mุงููุตู ุงูุนุงุดุฑ: ุงูููููุฉ ุงูููุฑูุฉ [0m

(1) 

Harold Smith Reeves, โProperty in Cyberspace,โ [3mUniversity of Chicago Law Review [0m63 (1996): 761. 

(2) 

This in the end was not his conclusion. He concluded instead, not that boundaries should not be protected in cyberspace, but 
rather that the unconventional nature of cyberspace requires that boundaries be set along nontraditional context-specific lines. 
This conclusion, Reeves asserts, requires the law to understand both the environment of cyberspace and the interests of those who 
transact in that space; see ibid., 799. 

(3) 

Cf. Yochai Benkler, โFree as the Air to Common Use: First Amendment Constraints on Enclosure of the Public Domain,โ [3mNew York 
University Law Review [0m74 (1999): 354. 

(4) 

Maureen OโRourke has extended the idea of the technological fences that cyberspace might provide, describing techniques that 
websites, for example, might use to control, or block, links from one site to another; see โFencing Cyberspace: Drawing Borders in 
a Virtual World,โ [3mMinnesota Law Review [0m82 (1998): 610, 645โ47. See, e.g., [3mThrifty-Tel, Inc. v. Bezenek, [0m46 Cal. App. 4th 1559 
(Cal. Ct. App. 1996) (Trespass to chattel claim involving defendantโs children hacking plaintiffโs confidential code to make long 
distance phone calls); [3mIntel v. Hamidi, [0m30 Cal. 4th 1342 (Cal. 2003) (Trespass to chattels claim involving Hamidi, a former 
employee, using Intelโs employee list-serve to send e-mails to employees); [3meBay v. Bidderโs Edge, [0m100 F. Supp. 2d 1058 (D. Cal. 
2000) (eBay sought to prevent Bidderโs Edge, an Internet-based auction aggregation site, from use of an automated query function 
without eBayโs authorization); [3mRegister.com v. Verio, [0m356 F. 3d 393 (2d. Cir. 2004) (Register.com sought to prevent Verio from 
using its trademark or online databases to solicit business from lists provided on the Register.com website); [3mAmerica Online, Inc. 
v. IMS, [0m1998 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20645 (D. Va. 1998) (America Online alleged that IMS was sending unsolicited bulk e-mail

(5) 

See, for example, Stephen Breyer, โThe Uneasy Case for Copyright: A Study of Copyright in Books, Photocopies, and Computer 
Programs,โ [3mHarvard Law Review [0m84 (1970): 281. 

(6) 

There is a ferocious debate about whether these separate forms of regulationโcopyright, patent, and trademarkโshould be referred 
to together as โIntellectual Property.โ I myself have gone both ways on this question, but currently believe it is harmful not to 
refer to these distinct bodies of law as โintellectual property.โ Though of course these domains are different, calling them by 
the same name doesnโt necessarily confuse (no one is confused about the difference between a tiger and a kitty cat, even if 
theyโre both called โcatsโ). More importantly, by not calling them by the same name, we lose a chance to point out inconsistencies 
in the way these different forms of property are treated. For example, both patent and trademark benefit from significant 
formalities built into each system; when you notice those formalities are absent from โcopyright,โ one is led to wonder why one 
form of โintellectual propertyโ is free of formalities, while the other two are not. 

(7) 

Paul Goldstein, [3mCopyrightโs Highway: From Gutenberg to the Celestial Jukebox [0m(Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2003) 64, 103: 
โLittle did I realize at the time that this was all going to have its effect on television and motion pictures and VCRs, and the 
whole gamut of things which are affected by copyright law, which of course werenโt even thought of when we made our move. We were 
dealing with a fairly simple operationโXerox. Now itโs become horribly complicated.โ 

(8) 

โIntellectual Property and the National Information Infrastructure: The Report of the Working Group on Intellectual Property 
Rights,โ U.S. Department of Commerce, 1995; hereafter โWhite Paper.โ George Smirnoff III (โCopyright on the Internet: A Critique 
of the White Paperโs Recommendation for Updating the Copyright Act and How the Courts Are Already Filling in Its Most Important 
Shortcoming, Online Service Provider Liability,โ [3mCleveland State Law Review [0m44 [1996]: 197) criticizes the White Paperโs lack of 
completeness, inconsistencies, and apparent lack of adequate consideration; see also Pamela Samuelson, โThe Copyright Grab,โ [3mWired [0m
(January 1996): 134, 136. By contrast, Gary W. Glisson (โA Practitionerโs Defense of the White Paper,โ [3mOregon Law Review 75 [0m
[1996]: 277) argues that the White Paper is neither a misleading summary of the state of intellectual property law nor a proposal 
for dramatic changes. For an extensive analysis of the copyright issues raised by cyberspace, see Trotter Hardy, โProject Looking 
Forward: Sketching the Future of Copyright in a Networked World,โ U.S. Copyright Office final report (1998), available at link 
#63.

(10) 

The most important such threat is the anticircumvention provision of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, which makes it a crime 
(subject to complex exceptions) to manufacture code to circumvent a copyright protection mechanism, even if the use of the 
underlying material itself would be a fair use; see Pub.L. 105โ304, 112 Stat 2877 (1998) (prohibiting the manufacture, 
importation, or distribution of โdevices, products, componentsโ that โdefeat technological methods of preventing unauthorized 
useโ).

See John Perry Barlow, โThe Economy of Ideas,โ [3mWired [0m(March 1994), 129; see also John Perry Barlow, โPapers and Comments of a

argues that โit is not so easy to own that which has never had any physical dimension whatsoever,โ unlike traditional forms of 
property. โWe have tended to think,โ he adds, โthat copyright worked well because it was physically difficult to transport 
intellectual properties without first manifesting them in some physical form. And it is no longer necessary to do that.โ

see Harold Demsetz, โToward a Theory of Property Rights,โ [3mAmerican Economics Review [0m57 (1967): 347. 

(26) 

For a wonderfully clear introduction to this point, as well as a complete analysis of the law, see Robert P. Merges et al., [3m
Intellectual Property in the New Technological Age [0m(New York: Aspen Law and Business, 1997), ch. 1. 

(27) 

Thomas Jefferson, letter to Isaac Mcpherson, August 13, 1813, reprinted in [3mWritings of Thomas Jefferson, 1790โ1826, [0mvol. 6, edited 
by H. A. Washington (1854), 180-81, quoted in [3mGraham v. John Deere Company, [0m383 US 1, 8-9 n.2 (1966). 

(28) 

For the classic discussion, see Kenneth J. Arrow, โEconomic Welfare and the Allocation of Resources for Invention,โ in [3mThe Rate 
and Direction of Inventive Activity: Economic and Social Factors [0m(Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1962), 609, 616-17. 

(29) 

For a powerfully compelling problematization of the economic perspective in this context, see Boyle, โIntellectual Property Policy 
Online,โ 35โ46. Boyleโs work evinces the indeterminacy that economics ought to profess about whether increasing property rights 
over information will also increase the production of information. 

(30) 

Some insist on calling this โpropertyโ; see Frank H. Easterbrook, โIntellectual Property Is Still Property,โ [3mHarvard Journal of 
Law and Public Policy [0m13 (1990): 108. 

(31) 

This is the message of Justice Stephen Breyerโs work on copyright, for example, โThe Uneasy Case for Copyright.โ 

(32) 

See [3mEldred v. Ashcroft, [0m537 U.S. 186 (2003). 

(33) 

For an extensive and balanced analysis, see William M. Landes and Richard A. Posner, โAn Economic Analysis of Copyright Law,โ [3m
Journal of Legal Studies [0m18 (1989): 325, 325โ27, 344โ46. These authors note that because ideas are a public goodโthat is, an 
infinite number of people can use an idea without using it upโideas are readily appropriated from the creator by other people. 
Hence, copyright protection attempts to balance efficiently the benefits of creating new works with the losses from limiting 
access and the costs of administering copyright protection; copyright protection seeks to promote the public benefit of advancing 
knowledge and learning by means of an incentive system. The economic rewards of the marketplace are offered to authors in order to 
stimulate them to produce and disseminate new works (326). See also Richard Posner, [3mLaw and Literature [0m(Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard 
University Press, 1998), 389โ405; William M. Landes and Richard Posner, [3mThe Economic Structure of Intellectual Property Law [0m
(Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 2003), 8-9. 

(34) 

These limits come from both the limits in the copyright clause, which sets its purposes out quite clearly, and the First 
Amendment; see, for example, [3mFeist Publications, Inc. v. Rural Telephone Service Co., [0m499 US 340, 346 (1991). 

(35) 

The โfirst saleโ doctrine was developed under 27 of the former Copyright Act (17 USC [1970]) and has since been adopted under 
109(a) of the present Copyright Act; see [3mUnited States v. Goss, [0m803 F2d 638 (11th Cir 1989) (discussing both versions of the 
Copyright Act). 

(36) 

Europeans like to say that โmoral rightsโ have been part of their system since the beginning of time, but as Professor Jane C. 
Ginsburg has shown with respect to France, they are actually a nineteenth-century creation; see โA Tale of Two Copyrights: 
Literary Property in Revolutionary France and America,โ [3mTulane Law Review [0m64 (1990): 991. 

(37) 

Daniel Benoliel, โTechnological Standards, Inc.: Rethinking Cyberspace Regulative Epistemology,โ 92 [3mCalifornia Law Review [0m1069, 
1114 (2004).

Owning Information: Intellectual Property and Restitutionary Impulse,โ [3mVirginia Law Review [0m78 (1992): 149. In โReality as Artifact 
From Feist to Fair Useโ ( [3mLaw and Contemporary Problems [0m55 5PG [1992]: 93, 96), Gordon observes that, while imaginative works are 
creative, they may also comprise facts, which need to be widely available for public dissemination. Gordonโs โToward a

[1990]: 1009) is a discussion of the ability of copyright holders to deny access to critics and others; see also Wendy Gordon, โAn

(46)

(49) 

As one commentator put it near the turn of the century: โIf the power of Congress has a wider incidence in 1918 than it could have 
had in 1789, this is merely because production is more dependent now than then on extra-state markets. No state liveth to itself 
alone to any such extent as was true a century ago. What is changing is not our system of government, but our economic 
organizationโ; Thomas Reed Powell, โThe Child Labor Law, the Tenth Amendment, and the Commerce Clause,โ [3mSouthern Law Quarterly [0m3 
(1918): 175, 200-201. 

(50)

(51) 

See [3mMaryland v. Wirtz, [0m392 US 183, 201 (1968) (Justice William O. Douglas dissenting: The majorityโs bringing of employees of

Tenth Amendment that it โฆ [was] not consistent with our constitutional federalismโ); [3mState Board of Insurance v. Todd Shipyards

regulation or taxation or to withhold it is so complete that its ideas of policy should prevailโ) (citations omitted). 

(52) 

See Michael G. Frey, โUnfairly Applying the Fair Use Doctrine: Princeton University Press v Michigan Document Services, 99 F3d 
1381 (6th Cir 1996),โ [3mUniversity of Cincinnati Law Review [0m66 (1998): 959, 1001; Frey asserts that โcopyright protection exists 
primarily for the benefit of the public, not the benefit of individual authors. Copyright law does give authors a considerable 
benefit in terms of the monopolistic right to control their creations, but that right exists only to ensure the creation of new 
works. The fair use doctrine is an important safety valve that ensures that the benefit to individual authors does not outweigh 
the benefit to the publicโ; Marlin H. Smith (โThe Limits of Copyright: Property, Parody, and the Public Domain,โ [3mDuke Law Journal [0m
42 [1993]: 1233, 1272) asserts that โcopyright law is better understood as that of a gatekeeper, controlling access to copyrighted 
works but guaranteeing, via fair use, some measure of availability to the public.โ

(65)

(67)

important foundations, however, to this argument. See, for example, Benjamin Kaplan, [3mAn Unhurried View of Copyright [0m(New York:

uncompensated transfers that the market is incapable of effectuating; see also Wendy J. Gordon, โOn Owning Information:

(68) 

In the first edition to this book, in addition to Boyle, I acknowledged broadly the work that had informed my understanding, 
including Keith Aoki, โForeword to Innovation and the Information Environment: Interrogating the Entrepreneur,โ [3mOregon Law Review [0m
75 (1996): 1; in โ(Intellectual) Property and Sovereignty,โ Aoki discusses the challenges to the traditional concept of property 
that arise from the growth of digital information technology; in โAuthors, Inventors, and Trademark Owners: Private Intellectual 
Property and the Public Domainโ [3m(Columbia-VLA Journal of Law and the Arts [0m18 [1993]: 1), he observes the shifting boundaries in 
intellectual property law between โpublicโ and โprivateโ realms of information and argues that trends to increase the number of 
exclusive rights for authors are converting the public domain into private intellectual property and constraining other types of 
socially valuable uses of expressive works that do not fit the โauthorshipโ model underlying American copyright traditions; he 
also argues that recent expansion of trademark law has allowed trademark owners to obtain property rights in their trademarks that 
do not further the Lanham Actโs goal of preventing consumer confusion. Benkler, โFree as the Air to Common Useโ; Yochai Benkler, 
โOvercoming Agoraphobia: Building the Commons of the Digitally Networked Environment,โ [3mHarvard Journal of Law and Technology [0m11 
(1998): 287; Julie E. Cohen, โCopyright and the Jurisprudence of Self-Help,โ [3mBerkeley Technology Law Journal [0m13 (1998): 1089; 
Julie E. Cohen, โLochner in Cyberspace: The New Economic Orthodoxy of โRights Management,โโ [3mMichigan Law Review [0m97 (1998): 462; 
Julie E. Cohen, โSome Reflections on Copyright Management Systems and Laws Designed to Protect Them,โ [3mBerkeley Technology Law 
Journal [0m12 (1997): 161, 181-82; Julie E. Cohen, โReverse-Engineering and the Rise of Electronic Vigilantism: Intellectual Property 
Implications of โLock-Outโ Programs,โ [3mSouthern California Law Review [0m68 (1995): 1091. Niva Elkin-Koren, โContracts in Cyberspace: 
Rights Without Laws,โ [3mChicago-Kent Law Review [0m73 (1998); Niva Elkin-Koren, โCopyright Policy and the Limits of Freedom of 
Contract,โ [3mBerkeley Technology Law Journal [0m12 (1997): 93, 107โ10 (criticizing the ProCD decision); Niva Elkin-Koren, โCyberlaw and 
Social Change: A Democratic Approach to Copyright Law in Cyberspace,โ [3mCardozo Arts and Entertainment Law Journal [0m14 (1996): 215; 
in โCopyright Law and Social Dialogue on the Information Superhighway: The Case Against Copyright Liability of Bulletin Board 
Operatorsโ ( [3mCardozo Arts and Entertainment Law Journal [0m13 [1995]: 345, 390โ99), Elkin-Koren analyzes the problems created by 
applying copyright law in a digitized environment. In โGoodbye to All ThatโA Reluctant (and Perhaps Premature) Adieu to a 
Constitutionally Grounded Discourse of Public Interest in Copyright Lawโ [3m(Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law [0m29 [1996]: 595), 
Peter A. Jaszi advocates the development of new, policy-grounded arguments and constitutionally based reasoning to battle 
expansionist legislative and judicial tendencies in copyright to diminish public access to the โintellectual commonsโ; see also 
Peter A. Jaszi, โOn the Author Effect: Contemporary Copyright and Collective Creativity,โ [3mCardozo Arts and Entertainment Law 
Journal [0m10 (1992): 293, 319-20; Peter A. Jaszi, โToward a Theory of Copyright: The Metamorphoses of โAuthorship,โโ [3mDuke Law 
Journal [0m1991 (1991): 455. On the misuse of copyright, see Mark A. Lemley, โBeyond Preemption: The Law and Policy of Intellectual 
Property Licensing,โ 87 [3mCalifornia Law Review, [0m111 (1999); Mark A. Lemley, โThe Economics of Improvement in Intellectual Property 
Law,โ [3mTexas Law Review [0m75 (1997): 989, 1048โ68; in โIntellectual Property and Shrink-wrap Licensesโ ( [3mSouthern California Law 
Review [0m68 [1995]: 1239, 1239), Lemley notes that โsoftware vendors are attempting en masse to โopt outโ of intellectual property 
law by drafting license provisions that compel their customers to adhere to more restrictive provisions than copyright โฆ law would 
require.โ Jessica Litman (โThe Tales That Article 2B Tells,โ [3mBerkeley Technology Law Journal [0m13 [1998]: 931, 938) characterizes as 
โdubiousโ the notion that current law enables publishers to make a transaction into a license by so designating it. In her view, 
article 2B is โconfusing and confusedโ about copyright and its relationship with that law, and would make new law. She believes 
that โwhatever the outcomeโ of the debate over whether copyright makes sense in the digital environment (see โReforming 
Information Law in Copyrightโs Image,โ [3mDayton Law Review [0m22 [1997]: 587, 590), โcopyright doctrine is ill-adapted to accommodate 
many of the important interests that inform our information policy. First Amendment, privacy, and distributional issues that 
copyright has treated only glancingly are central to any information policy.โ See also Jessica Litman, โRevising Copyright Law for 
the Information Age,โ [3mOregon Law Review [0m75 (1996): 19; and โThe Exclusive Right to Readโ ( [3mCardozo Arts and Entertainment Law 
Journal [0m13 [1994]: 29, 48), in which Litman states that โmuch of the activity on the net takes place on the mistaken assumption 
that any material on the Internet is free from copyright unless expressly declared to be otherwise.โ In โCopyright as Mythโ ( [3m
University of Pittsburgh Law Review [0m53 [1991]: 235, 235โ37), Litman provides a general overview of the issues of authorship and 
infringement in copyright law, indicating that debate continues regarding the definition of โauthorshipโ (she defines โauthorโ โin 
the copyright sense of anyone who creates copyrightable works, whether they be books, songs, sculptures, buildings, computer 
programs, paintings or filmsโ [236, n.5]); she also discusses why copyright law is counterintuitive to the authorship process. See 
also โThe Public Domainโ ( [3mEmory Law Journal [0m39 [1990]: 965, 969), in which Litman recommends a broad definition of the public 
domain (โoriginality is a keystone of copyright lawโ [974]). Neil Weinstock Netanel, โAsserting Copyrightโs Democratic Principles 
in the Global Arena,โ [3mVanderbilt Law Review [0m51 (1998): 217, 232 n.48, 299 n.322; Neil Netanel, โAlienability Restrictions and the 
Enhancement of Author Autonomy in United States and Continental Copyright Law,โ [3mCardozo Arts and Entertainment Law Journal [0m12 
(1994): 1, 42-43; in โ[C]opyright and a Democratic Civil Societyโ ( [3mYale Law Journal [0m106 [1996]: 283, 288, 324โ36), Netanel 
analyzes copyright law and policy in terms of its democracy-enhancing function: โCopyright is in essence a state measure that uses 
market institutions to enhance the democratic character of society.โ Margaret Jane Radin and Polk Wagner, โThe Myth of Private 
Ordering: Rediscovering Legal Realism in Cyberspace,โ [3mChicago-Kent Law Review [0m73 (1998); Margaret Jane Radin, [3mReinterpreting 
Property [0m(Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1993), 56โ63. Pam Samuelson, โEncoding the Law into Digital Libraries,โ [3m
Communications of the ACM [0m41 (1999): 13, 13-14; Pamela Samuelson, foreword to โSymposium: Intellectual Property and Contract Law 
for the Information Age,โ [3mCalifornia Law Review [0m87 (1998): 1; Pamela Samuelson observes in โEmbedding Technical Self-Help in 
Licensed Softwareโ (Communications of the ACM 40 [1997]: 13, 16) that โlicensors of software or other information โฆ will generally 
invoke self-helpโ; see also the criticism of the European database directive in J. H. Reichman and Pamela Samuelson, โIntellectual 
Property Rights in Data?,โ [3mVanderbilt Law Review [0m50 (1997): 51, 84โ95; Samuelson, โThe Copyright Grab,โ 134; Pamela Samuelson, 
โFair Use for Computer Programs and Other Copyrightable Works in Digital Form: The Implications of Sony, Galoob and Sega,โ [3mJournal 
of Intellectual Property Law [0m1 (1993): 49. There is much more that I have learned from in the last seven years. But rather than 
replicating the listing style, I would point to Jessica Litman, [3mDigital Copyright: Protecting Intellectual Property on the 
Internet [0m(Amherst, N.Y.: Prometheus Books, 2000); Vaidhyanathan, [3mCopyrights and Copywrongs; [0mWilliam Fisher, [3mPromises to Keep: 
Technology, Law, and the Future of Entertainment [0m(Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2004), and Benkler, [3mThe Wealth of Networks. [0m

Boyle, [3mShamans, Software, and Spleens. [0mFor other compelling accounts of the general movement to propertize information, see Debora

1999). Seth Shulmanโs [3mOwning the Future [0m(Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1999) gives the story its appropriate drama. [3mInternet

(13) 

Weโve learned that the Defense Department is deeply involved in domestic intelligence (intelligence concerning threats to national 
security that unfold on U.S. soil). The departmentโs National Security Agency has been conducting, outside the framework of the 
Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, electronic surveillance of U.S. citizens within the United States. Other Pentagon agencies, 
notably the one known as Counterintelligence Field Activity (CIFA), have, as described in Walter Pincusโs recent articles in the [3m
Washington Post, [0mbeen conducting domestic intelligence on a large scale. Although the CIFAโs formal mission is to prevent attacks 
on military installations in the United States, the scale of its activities suggests a broader concern with domestic security. 
Other Pentagon agencies have gotten into the domestic intelligence act, such as the Information Dominance Center, which developed 
the Able Danger data-mining program. Richard Posner, โOur Domestic Intelligence Crisis,โ [3mWashington Post, [0mDecember 21, 2005, at 
A31.

(30) 

See Janai S. Nelson, โResidential Zoning Regulations and the Perpetuation of Apartheid,โ [3mUCLA Law Review [0m43 (1996): 1689,
