(31) 

Examples of laws that aim at segregation based on social or economic criteria include: regulations requiring a minimum lot size 
for housing; single-family ordinances prohibiting โnontraditionalโ families from living in certain areas; and residential 
classifications that exclude apartment housing. All such restrictions significantly increase the cost of housing for lower-income 
individuals; see ibid., 1699-1700. 

(32) 

In 1926 the Supreme Court held zoning to be a valid exercise of local governmental power. See [3mVillage of Euclid v. Ambler Realty 
Company, [0m272 US 365 (1926) (holding that a state has the right to separate incompatible uses). Not until the twentieth century 
were municipalities given much power to regulate areas of law such as zoning decisions; see Richard Briffault, โOur Localism: Part 
IโThe Structure of Local Government Law,โ [3mColumbia Law Review [0m90 (1990): 1, 8โ11, 19. 

(33) 

In 1917 the Supreme Court outlawed racial zoning as a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment; see [3mBuchanan v. Warley, [0m245 US 60 
(1917). However, โnonexclusionaryโ zoning regulation was used to preserve residential segregation; even though racially neutral 
and based on economic factors (ostensibly to prevent property devaluation), various laws and regulations have resulted in de facto 
segregation; see Briffault, โOur Localism,โ 103-4; Meredith Lee Bryant, โCombating School Resegregation Through Housing: A Need 
for a Reconceptualization of American Democracy and the Rights It Protects,โ [3mHarvard BlackLetter Journal [0m13 (1997): 127, 131-32. 

(34) 

See Joel Kosman, โToward an Inclusionary Jurisprudence: A Reconceptualization of Zoning,โ [3mCatholic University Law Review [0m43 
(1993): 59, 77โ86, 101โ3. 

(35) 

See Gordon S. Wood, [3mThe Radicalism of the American Revolution [0m(New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1992), 5โ8, 271โ86. 

(36) 

See Lynne G. Zucker, โProduction of Trust: Institutional Sources of Economic Structure, 1840โ1920,โ [3mResearch in Organizational 
Behavior [0m8 (1986): 53. 

(37) 

Price discrimination is the ability to charge different prices for the same good. Airplane tickets are the best exampleโthe same 
seat can cost hundreds of dollars more for a traveler who cannot stay over Saturday night. See, for example, Joseph Gregory Sidak, 
โDebunking Predatory Innovation,โ [3mColumbia Law Review [0m83 (1983): 1121, 1132โ35; see also Easterbrook, โIntellectual Property Is 
Still Propertyโ; Fisher, โReconstructing the Fair Use Doctrine,โ 1659; but see Janusz A. Ordover et al., โPredatory Systems 
Rivalry: A Reply,โ [3mColumbia Law Review [0m83 (1983): 1150, 1158โ64. 

(38) 

Viviana A. Zelizer, [3mThe Social Meaning of Money, [0m2d ed. (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1994), 94-95 (footnote omitted). 

(39) 

Susan Brenner puts the point very powerfully. As she frames the question, โis it reasonable to translate the values incorporate in 
the Fourth Amendment into a context created and sustained by technology?โ Susan Brenner, โThe Privacy Privilege: Law Enforcement, 
Technology and the Constitution,โ [3mJournal of Technology Law and Policy [0m7 (2002): 123, 162. The question isnโt simply whether 
anonymity has a valueโplainly it does. The question instead is โhow to translate rights devised to deal with real world conduct 
into [a world where] greater degrees of anonymity are possible โฆโ Ibid., 139-40. โBecause the technology alters the contours of 
the empirical environment in which the right to remain anonymous is exercised, it creates a tension between this aspect of the 
right to be let alone and the needs of effective law enforcement.โ Ibid., 144. 

(40) 

Shawn C. Helms, โTranslating Privacy Values with Technology,โ [3mBoston University Journal of Science and Technology Law [0m7 (2001): 
288, 314. (โWe should approach the translation of anonymity on the Internet through โcodeโ by developing and implementing 
privacy-enhancing technologies.โ) 

(41) 

As William McGeveran writes, Marc Rotenberg, one of privacyโs most important advocate, doesnโt view P3P as a PET โbecause 
Rotenberg defines a PET as technology that inherently reduces transfer of personal data.โ William McGeveran, โProgrammed Privacy 
Promises: P3P and Web Privacy Law,โ [3mNew York University Law Review [0m76 (2001): 1813, 1826-27 n.80. I share McGeveranโs view that 
P3P is a PET. If privacy is control over how information about you is released, then a technology that enhances that control is a 
PET even if it doesnโt โreduce [the] transfer of personal dataโโso long as that reduction is consistent with the preferences of 
the individual. No doubt, a PET could be a bad PET to the extent it fails to enable choice. But it isnโt a bad PET because it 
fails to enable the choice of someone other than the consumer. For a wonderful account of how norms have risen to change data 
privacy practice, see Steven A. Hetcher, โNorm Proselytizers Create a Privacy Entitlement in Cyberspace,โ [3mBerkeley Technology Law 
Journal [0m16 (2001): 877. 

(42) 

See U.S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Secretaryโs Advisory Committee on Automated Personal Data Systems, Records, 
Computers, and the Rights of Citizens viii (1973), cited at link #76. 

(43) 

Ibid. 

(44) 

Lior Jacob Strahilevitz nicely explores this fundamentally โempiricalโ question in โA Social Networks Theory of Privacy,โ [3m
University of Chicago Law Review [0m72 (2005): 919, 921. 

(45) 

See Guido Calabresi and A. Douglas Melamed, โProperty Rules, Liability Rules, and Inalienability: One View of the Cathedral,โ [3m
Harvard Law Review [0m85 (1972): 1089, 1105-6. โProperty rules involve a collective decision as to who is to be given an initial 
entitlement but not as to the value of the entitlement โฆ Liability rules involve an additional stage of state intervention: not 
only are entitlements protected, but their transfer or destruction is allowed on the basis of a value determined by some organ of 
the state rather than by the parties themselvesโ (1092).

(50) 

The important limit to contracts, however, is that they typically bind only people โwithin privity,โ meaning parties to the 
contract. Thus, an agreement I enter in with you about how you promise not to use a book Iโve sold you (e.g., a promise not to 
review it before a certain date) wonโt bind someone else who comes across the book and reads it. 

(51) 

As described above, the weakness is linked to the point above about โprivity.โ Unlike a rule of property that travels 
automatically with the property, a rule built out of agreements reaches only as far as the agreements. 

(52) 

Barlow, โThe Economy of Ideas,โ [3mWired [0m(March 1994), available at link #77 (โinformation wants to be freeโ).

(3) 

Built by industry but also especially by Cypherpunksโcoders dedicated to building the tools for privacy for the Internet. As Eric 
Hughes writes in โA Cypherpunkโs Manifestoโ (in [3mApplied Cryptography, [0m2d ed., by Bruce Schneier [New York: Wiley, 1996], 609): โWe 
the Cypherpunks are dedicated to building anonymous systems. We are defending our privacy with cryptography, with anonymous mail 
forwarding systems, with digital signatures, and with electronic money. Cypherpunks write code. We know that someone has to write 
software to defend privacy, and since we canโt get privacy unless we all do, weโre going to write it. We publish our code so that 
our fellow Cypherpunks may practice and play with it. Our code is free for all to use, worldwide.โ

(15) 

The standard arguments are summarized well by Kathleen M. Sullivan and Gerald Gunther: โ(1) It is easier for an official to 
restrict speech โby a simple stroke of the penโ than by the more cumbersome apparatus of subsequent punishment โฆ (2) Censors will 
have a professional bias in favor of censorship, and thus will systematically overvalue government interests and undervalue 
speech. (3) Censors operate more informally than judges and so afford less procedural safeguards to speakers. (4) Speech 
suppressed in advance never reaches the marketplace of ideas at all. (5) When speech is suppressed in advance, there is no 
empirical evidence from which to measure its alleged likely harmsโ; [3mFirst Amendment Law [0m(New York: Foundation Press, 1999), 
339-40, citing Thomas Emerson, โThe Doctrine of Prior Restraint,โ [3mLaw and Contemporary Problems [0m20 (1955): 648. Frederick Schauer 
offers a nice balance to this commonplace theory; see โFear, Risk, and the First Amendment: Unraveling the โChilling Effect,โโ [3m
Boston University Law Review [0m58 (1978): 685, 725โ30. 

(16) 

In a particularly telling exchange, Justice Stewart asked Professor Bickel about a case in which disclosure โwould result in the 
sentencing to death of a hundred young men whose only offense had been that they were nineteen years old and had low draft 
numbers. What should we do?โ Bickel replied that his โinclinations of humanity overcome the somewhat more abstract devotion to the 
First Amendment in a case of that sortโ; [3mMay It Please the Court: The Most Significant Oral Arguments Made Before the Supreme 
Court Since 1955, [0medited by Peter Irons and Stephanie Guitton (New York: Free Press, 1993), 173. 

(17) 

In a concurring opinion, Justice Potter Stewart wrote that the prior restraint at issue was invalid since he could not โsay that 
disclosure of [the Pentagon Papers] will surely result in direct, immediate, and irreparable damage to our Nation or its peopleโ; [3m
New York Times Company v. United States, [0m403 US 713, 730 (1971) (per curiam). This standard has frequently been thought to reflect 
the position of the Court; see Laurence H. Tribe, [3mAmerican Constitutional Law [0m(Mineola, N.Y.: Foundation Press, 1978), 731; Morton 
H. Halperin and Daniel N. Hoffman, [3mTop Secret: National Security and the Right to Know [0m(Washington, D.C.: New Republic Books, 
1977), 147 n.22; see also [3mAlderman v. Philadelphia Housing Authority, [0m496 F2d 164, 170 (3d Cir 1974), cert. denied, 419 US 844 
(1974) (prior restraint must be supported by โcompelling proofโ that it is โessential to a vital government interestโ).

(33) 

[3mGinsburg v. New York [0m, 390 US 629 (1968). Obscenity is not constitutionally protected speech, and federal laws prohibit the 
transportation of obscene materials; see 18 USCA 1462 (1984), amended by 18 USCA 1462 (Supp 1999). In [3mMiller v. California, [0mthe 
Supreme Court described the test for obscenity as: โ(a) whether โthe average person, applying contemporary community standardsโ 
would find that the work, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest; (b) whether the work depicts or describes, in a 
patently offensive way, sexual conduct specifically defined by the applicable state law; and (c) whether the work, taken as a 
whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific valueโ; [3mMiller v. California, [0m413 US 15, 24 (1973) (5-4 
decision), rehearing denied, 414 US 881 (1973). Porn, on the other hand, is protected by the First Amendment but may be regulated 
to promote the stateโs interest in protecting children from harmful materials so long as the regulation is the least restrictive 
means to further the articulated interest; see [3mGinsberg v. New York, [0m390 US 629, 637โ40 (1968). Child porn may be prohibited as 
obscene material even if it is not obscene under the Miller test, owing to the strong state interest in preventing the sexual 
exploitation of children; see [3mNew York v. Ferber, [0m458 US 747, 764 (1982). Child porn is not constitutionally protected, and 
federal law prohibits the transportation of child porn; see 18 USCA 2252 (1984), amended by 18 USCA 2252 (Supp 1999). 

(34) 

Justice Sandra Day OโConnor listed more than 40 states with such law in her concurrence in [3mReno v. ACLU, [0m521 US 844, 887 n.2. 

(35) 

[3mGinsberg v. New York, [0m390 US 629 (1968). 

(36) 

See Blake T. Bilstad, โObscenity and Indecency in a Digital Age: The Legal and Political Implications of Cybersmut, Virtual 
Pornography, and the Communications Decency Act of 1996,โ [3mSanta Clara Computer and High Technology Law Journal [0m13 (1997): 321, 
336-37. 

(37) 

Marty Rimm, โMarketing Pornography on the Information Superhighway: A Survey of 917, 410 Images, Descriptions, Short Stories, and 
Animations Downloaded 8.5 Million Times by Consumers in over 2, 000 Cities in Forty Countries, Provinces, and Territories,โ [3m
Georgetown University Law Journal [0m83 (1995): 1849. Godwin provides the whole history of the Rimm article, describing the most 
significant problems and consequences of the โmisleadingโ and โfalseโ statements, and its eventual demise; [3mCyber Rights, [0m206โ59; 
see also Jonathan Wallace and Mark Mangan, [3mSex, Laws, and Cyberspace [0m(New York: M&T Books, 1996), ch. 6.

(41) 

See [3mFederal Communications Commission v. Pacifica Foundation, [0m438 US 726, 748โ50 (1978) (plurality). Though Pacifica has been

Cities,โ [3mConnecticut Law Review [0m30 [1998]: 1199, 1200), explains how universities erect borders to divorce themselves from 
surrounding poverty and argues that universities should critique these borders; Lani Guinier (โMore Democracy,โ [3mUniversity of 
Chicago Legal Forum [0m1995 [1995]: 1, 3) advocates a cross-racial participatory democracy that demands a concern for, and a

(57) 

Dan Hunter argues it is not our choice anyway. See Dan Hunter, โPhilippic.com,โ [3mCalifornia Law Review [0m90 (2002): 611. Greg 
Laughlin is convinced the concerns are overstated. See Gregory K. Laughlin, โSex, Lies, and Library Cards: The First Amendment 
Implications of the Use of Software Filters to Control Access to Internet Pornography in Public Libraries,โ [3mDrake Law Review [0m51 
(2003): 213, 267-68 n.287. For a review of Congressโs latest effort to facilitate filtering, see Susan P. Crawford, Symposium, 
โLaw and the Information Society, Panel V: Responsibility and Liability on the Internet, Shortness of Vision: Regulatory Ambition 
in the Digital Age,โ [3mFordham Law Review [0m74 (2005): 1, 6. (โThe next information-flow membrane mandate to pass Congressโagain, 
prompted by legislatorsโ fixation on indecent (but legal) content onlineโwas the Childrenโs Internet Protection Act (โCIPAโ), 
which required libraries to install filtering software on all their computers capable of accessing the Internet in order to hold 
on to their federal funding. The goal of this 2000 legislation was to condition provision of such funding on librariesโ use of 
filters that block access to visual depictions that are harmful to minors (when accessed by a minor). On June 23, 2003, after 
another three years of litigation, the Supreme Court upheld CIPA, with two โswingโ Justices (Anthony Kennedy and Stephen Breyer) 
suggesting that adults would be able to ask libraries to unblock legal sites (legal for adult viewing, if harmful to minors) that 
had been blocked by the installed filters. Even though the tie to the CDA was clearโthis was another congressional attempt to 
eliminate online sexual material using technology that would also inevitably filter out protected speechโthe link to federal 
funding made this case one the Justices could decide differently. Indeed, the federal funding element may have been the crucial 
difference between CDA and CIPA. One European commentator noted the CIPA opinion as an โimportant shiftโ by an American legal 
system that had been โpreviously critical of governmentโs attempts to regular Internet access.โโ)

(63) 

Jonathan Zdziarski, [3mEnding Spam: Bayesian Content Filtering and the Art of Statistical Language Classification [0m(San Francisco: No

(64) 

See CAN-SPAM Act of 2003, Public Law 108โ187 (2003). For a review of European legislation, see D. I. Cojocarasu, [3mAnti-spam 
Legislation Between Privacy and Commercial Interest: An Overview of the European Union Legislation Regarding the E-mail Spam [0m
(Oslo: University of Oslo, 2006). In my view, we define spam as โunsolicited bulk commercial e-mail.โ Each element is necessary. 
Unsolicited, meaning there is no agreement to receive such e-mail. If there is an agreement, the requirements would be removed. 
Bulk meaning it would not be intended to regulate circulations to friends or within small groups. Cf. Sonia Arrison, โCanning 
Spam: An Economic Solution to Unwanted Emailโ 9 (Pacific Research Institute, Feb. 2004). Commercial meaning it would not regulate 
social or political e-mail. And e-mail, meaning maybe more than e-mailโperhaps, for example, including blog spam. 

(65) 

In my view, Congress should be permitted to discriminate in favor of political speech, and should thus be permitted to exempt 
political speech from any โspamโ regulation. This is not only because of the special value in this speech, but also, and more 
importantly, because abuse with political speech is more naturally regulated. If I am trying to win your vote, Iโm not likely to 
annoy you with spam. But if Iโm trying to sell you Viagra, whether I annoy you or not wonโt matter much to me. 

(66) 

This was the law in many states before the federal CAN-SPAM Act preempted this state law. But as those laws didnโt have the 
enforcement remedy I propose here, they are not directly relevant to the argument I am making here. See โSubject Line Labeling as 
a Weapon Against Spam,โ A CAN-SPAM Act Report of Congress (FTC June 2005). This solution is just one instance of a general form 
which aims to shift the burden of revealing information to the sender. For a much more sophisticated proposal, see Theodore Loder, 
Marshall Van Alstyne, and Rick Wash (2006) โAn Economic Response to Unsolicited Communicationโ, [3mAdvances in Economic Analysis and 
Policy [0mVol. 6, No. 1, Article 2, available at link #98.

(80) 

Ethernet effectively functions like this. Data on an Ethernet network are streamed into each machine on that network. Each machine 
sniffs the data and then pays attention to the data intended for it. This process creates an obvious security hole: โsniffersโ can 
be put on โpromiscuous modeโ and read packets intended for other machines; see Loshin, [3mTCP/IP Clearly Explained, [0m44โ46. 

(81) 

See Yochai Benkler and Lawrence Lessig, โNet Gains,โ [3mNew Republic, [0mDecember 14, 1998. 

(82) 

The founder of this argument must be Eli Noam; see โSpectrum Auctions: Yesterdayโs Heresy, Todayโs Orthodoxy, Tomorrowโs 
AnachronismโTaking the Next Step to Open Spectrum [3mAccessโ Journal of Law and Economics [0m41 (1998): 765. Benkler has spiced it up a 
bit (in my view, in critical ways) by adding to it the value of the commons. For an extraordinarily powerful push to a similar 
political (if not technological) end, see Eben Moglen, โThe Invisible Barbecue,โ [3mColumbia Law Review [0m97 (1997): 945. Moglen notes 
the lack of debate regarding the sociopolitical consequences of carving up telecommunication rights at the โGreat Barbecueโ and 
draws a parallel with the Gilded Ageโs allocation of benefits and privileges associated with the railroad industry.

Article V of the Constitution states (obscurely no doubt) that โprovided that no Amendment which may be made prior to the Year One 
thousand eight hundred and eight shall in any Manner affect the first and fourth Clauses in the Ninth Section of the first 
Article.โ These clauses state: โ(1) The Migration or Importation of such Persons as any of the States now existing shall think 
proper to admit, shall not be prohibited by the Congress prior to the Year one thousand eight hundred and eight, but a Tax or duty 
may be imposed on such Importation, not exceeding ten Dollars for each Personโ; and โ(4) No Capitation, or other direct, Tax shall 
be laid, unless in Proportion to the Census or Enumeration herein before directed to be taken.โ

Copyright Act (P.L. 105โ304), enacted October 28, 1998; Fairness in Music Licensing Act of 1998 (P.L. 105โ298), enacted October 
27, 1998. (Amending ยง 110 and adding ยง 513 to provide a music licensing exemption for food service and drinking establishments.);

Lessig, โThe New Chicago School,โ 661. 

(2)

(3)

to be known as the birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Within 10 days before the birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., in 
each year the Governor shall issue a proclamation announcing the holiday and designating the official events that shall be held in 
honor of the memory of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and his contributions to this nationโ; 5 Illinois Comprehensive Statutes 
Annotated 490/65 (West 1998).

See Robert Cooter, โExpressive Law and Economics,โ [3mJournal of Legal Studies [0m27 (1998): 585. 

(5) 

Cf. Paul N. Bracken, [3mThe Command and Control of Nuclear Forces [0m(New Haven: Yale University Press, 1983), 179โ237; Christopher 
chant and Ian Hogg, [3mThe Nuclear War File [0m(London: Ebury Press, 1983), 68โ115. 

(6) 

On the other side, the military built into the system technological brakes on the ability to launch, to ensure that no decision to 
launch was ever too easy; see also Daniel Ford, [3mThe Button: The Nuclear TriggerโDoes It Work? [0m(London: Allen and Unwin, 1985), 
118โ21. 

(7) 

โThe phenomena of social meaning and incommensurability constrain rational choice (individual and collective). Generalizing, it is 
irrational to treat goods as commensurable where the use of a quantitative metric effaces some dimension of meaning essential to 
oneโs purposes or goals. It would be irrational, for example, for a person who wanted to be a good colleague within an academic 
community to offer another scholar cash instead of comments on her manuscript. Against the background of social norms, the 
commentโs signification of respect cannot be reproduced by any amount of money; even to attempt the substitution conveys that the 
person does not value his colleague in the way appropriate to their relationshipโ; Dan M. Kahan, โPunishment Incommensurability,โ [3m
Buffalo Criminal Law Review [0m1 (1998): 691, 695. 

(8) 

Many scholars, Robert Cooter most prominently among them, argue that norms are special because they are โinternalizedโ in a sense 
that other constraints are not; see Robert D. Cooter, โDecentralized Law for a Complex Economy: The Structural Approach to 
Adjudicating the New Law Merchant,โ [3mUniversity of Pennsylvania Law Review [0m144 (1996): 1643, 1662; Robert D. Cooter, โThe Theory of 
Market Modernization of Law,โ [3mInternational Review of Law and Economics [0m16 (1996): 141, 153. By internalization, Cooter is just 
describing the same sort of subjectivity that happens with the child and fire: the constraint moves from being an objectively ex 
post constraint to a subjectively ex ante constraint. The norm becomes a part of the person, such that the person feels its 
resistance before he acts, and hence its resistance controls his action before he acts. Once internalized, norms no longer need to 
be enforced to have force; their force has moved inside, as it were, and continues within this subjective perspective. In my view, 
we should see each constraint functioning in the same way: We subjectively come to account for the constraint through a process of 
internalization. Some internalization incentives may be stronger than others, of course. But that is just a difference. 

(9) 

Cf. Dan M. Kahan, โIgnorance of Law Is an ExcuseโBut Only for the Virtuous,โ [3mMichigan Law Review [0m96 (1997): 127. 

(10) 

See, for example, Schuster et al., Preserving the Built Heritage; Peter Katz, [3mThe New Urbanism: Toward an Architecture of 
Community [0m(New York: McGraw-Hill, 1994); Duany and Plater-Zyberk, [3mTowns and Town-Making Principles. [0m

(11) 

Michael Sorkin, [3mLocal Code: The Constitution of a City at 42N Latitude [0m(New York: Princeton Architectural Press, 1993), 11, 127.
